Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Advancing the Engineering of Complex Systems through Automated Mechanism Design for Complex Network Formation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Traditional engineering methodologies have proven highly effective for designing complicated systems, such as automobiles and computers, where the sum of the parts equals the whole. However, these methodologies are not very useful for designing complex systems that are greater than the sum of their parts, such as global supply chains, the Internet of Things, social networks and smart power grids. The rapidly increasing and critical role such systems play in U.S. social, industrial and economic infrastructures necessitates new principles for designing complex systems in an inherently efficient, robust and sustainable fashion. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports fundamental research to provide engineering principles for designing such complex systems. Knowledge from several disciplines including computer science, game theory, optimization and machine learning is integral to this research. Moreover, the emphasis on complex systems will help broaden interest in engineering research and positively impact engineering education.

The highly interdependent nature of many physical, virtual and cyber-physical complex systems and our increasing reliance upon them, demand a sound basis upon which to base their design. This research will provide principles for designing complex systems by considering the problem as one of automated mechanism design within the context of strategic Bayesian network formation games to automatically devise incentives such that multiple global design objectives are achieved. The local and stochastic nature inherent to many complex systems motivates a behavior-based perspective on network formation rules, permitting the consideration of more realistic scenarios and may provide deeper insight into network formation itself. The research team will perform simulations, devise models and perform analytical derivations under different system design objectives in order to establish hidden relationships, vary complex system size to better understand adaptation and evolution, consider fixed system interactions to reveal the role of legacy or backbone infrastructure on future systems and mechanisms, and integrate online machine learning as a means for providing feedback thus allowing for adaptive mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project conducted fundamental research aimed at providing engineering design principles for complex systems such as supply chains, social networks, and power grids. These systems are often summarized as complex networks, which are graphical representations of the system. Complicating the modeling problem is that the goal is not isomorphic replication of a particular system, but rather to yield an generator capable of synthesizing networks having both contextually important salient features, and natural topological variation. To this end, two novel frameworks were proposed and based on centralized and decentralized perspectives, respectively. Results demonstrated state-of-the-art ability to model and design real world networks from both perspectives, and provides a basis upon which to begin devising general design guidelines. 

The project established the action-based network generation model of complex networks. The fundamental idea follows directly from our current understanding of system emergence whereby the global structure arises from stochastic local interactions. By considering the modeling of such systems as a stochastic inverse problem, it was shown that a compact probabilistic representation can be efficiency estimated using standard multi-objective search or optimization algorithms. The framework is robust to the definition of network similarity, and can inherently include both abstract or context-specific local actions that give rise to the network connection structure. This centralized model is not only highly compact, but also gives researchers greater transparency into the underlying generative process. 

The project also provided a game-theoretic framework based on automated mechanism design to model and design complex networks in a decentralized fashion. The fundamental idea behind these complex network formation games is to discover optimal incentive mechanisms over a finite set of local actions for creating network connections, such that the resultant network has some desired global properties. A significant challenge that needed to be overcome was the requirement stated above, specifically the avoidance of isomorphic results. This was accomplished by defining a social utility function and stochastic setup that permitted such outcomes. Moreover, this framework provides the capability to consider multiple network features of interest. 

Apart from the novelty of the approaches, rigorous experimental studies provided evidence to support state-of-the-art practical performance for accurately modeling salient topological features and natural variation of complex systems using only a single network as input. Additionally, inspection of the resulting models has implied strategies that may be useful to design naturally robust systems, although further investigation is required to confirm this potential. Both frameworks represent advances in our broad ability to model and design systems from centralized and decentralized perspectives, and highlight the need for future work in this area. 

A graduate and undergraduate student were heavily involved in accomplishing the goals of this project, with the former gaining invaluable supervisory experience as well as important international exposure at academic conferences while presenting this research. Results were disseminated in highly reputable academic journals and conferences.
